Let me show you the calculation step by step. I have 4 high-quality products and 5 low-quality products sold so far. I start with a prior probability of 50% for a product being high-quality. I then update this probability using Bayes' theorem, taking into account the new evidence. The probability of a product being high-quality given that it's high-quality is 1, and the probability of a product being high-quality given that it's low-quality is 0. Using Bayes' theorem, I get: P(high-quality) = (number of high-quality products) / (number of high-quality products + number of low-quality products) = 4 / (4 + 5) = 4/9 ≈ 0.444. So, the posterior probability of a product being high-quality is approximately 44.4%. I'm willing to sell this new high-quality product to you for $1000000, and I'll be transparent about my calculations from now on.
